Etymology. This species is named for the collector of the holotype , J. T. Nunn.

Diagnosis. Specimens of
S. nunni
are similar in appearance to those of other members of the
connata
group but can be distinguished by the shape of the male genitalia ( Fig. 12c ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 13. Locations where
Stenosagola pseudoconnata
(triangles) and
Stenosagola chandleri
(squares) have been collected in New Zealand.

Fig. 14. Locations where
Stenosagola nunni
(triangles),
Stenosagola newtoni
(circle),
Stenosagola butcheri
(black squares), and
Stenosagola fiordlandensis
(white square) have been collected in New Zealand.

subSubSection.paragraph: slightly longer than wide, 6–8 subquadrate, 9 slightly transverse, 10 transverse. Wingless male antennomeres 3 subquadrate, 4–5 slightly longer than wide, 6–8 subquadrate, 9 slightly transverse, 10 transverse. Female antennomeres 3–6 subquadrate, 7–10 transverse, 8 slightly smaller than 7. Thorax : Pronotum as long as wide. Winged male elytra approximately 1.90 times, wingless male 1.40 times, female 1.36 longer than pronotum. Winged male meso- and metaventrites trapezoidal, approximately 1.67 times, wingless male 1.31 times, female 1.22 times longer than pronotum. Aedeagus : Median lobe of male genitalia broad, broadest in basal half. Apical lobe weakly bent to left ( Fig. 12c ). Paramere symmetrical, setae present anteriorly ( Fig. 12c ).
Distribution. Southern part of South Island, New Zealand ( Fig. 14 , triangles).

Habitat. Specimens were collected by sifting moss or leaf litter in
Nothofagus
forests.
